In some constructions, the modules for the light member are of different size or shape than the modules for another light member, such that the modules for each light member are only for use with a specific application. The light

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a cooled flow deflection apparatus for a fluid-flow machine that operates at high temperatures, particularly in the form of a cooled stator blade or rotor blade for a gas turbine.
2. The prior art flow deflection apparatuses have disadvantages such as a transitional region that is difficult to cool, thermal stresses between the separating walls and the hot-gas wall, high blade weight, and complex casting.
3. The object of the invention is to provide a cooled flow deflection apparatus that avoids the described disadvantages of the known apparatus and is simple to produce, can be flexibly matched to the respective application, and is efficiently cooled.
4. The invention achieves this object by constructing the separating walls as separate inserts that are subsequently inserted into the apparatus and secured there, rather than producing them jointly with the apparatus.
5. The use of inserts has several advantages, including reduced material in the transitional region, no thermal stresses between the insert and the hot-gas wall, reduced blade weight, and a simpler cast core.
6. A preferred embodiment of the flow deflection apparatus is in the form of a hollow casting with holders in the form of rails integrally formed in the interior, into which the separating walls are inserted.
7. The separating walls may be straight or bent into a U-shape, and can be secured on one or more sides by soldering or welding, and may be fixed in the blade tip region or in the blade root region.
8. The invention can be implemented by inserting the separating walls into a newly cast blade or by removing the cast separating walls from a completely cast blade and inserting separate separating walls as a substitute.</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a system and method for controlling the operation of a fuel delivery system for a vehicle, which can be switched between manual and automatic control. The system comprises a control unit that receives signals indicating accelerator pedal position and throttle valve position, and processes these signals to provide a control signal to a DC motor or stepper motor. The motor then sets the throttle position for optimum performance of the vehicle.

2. The system allows for smooth switching between automatic and manual control without causing the vehicle to lurch forward or stall, and provides full operation of the vehicle when under manual control. The control unit can detect a malfunction or fault and switch to manual control, and the system can also be used in conjunction with a continuously variable transmission. At high transmission ratios, it is desirable for the throttle valve to be directly controlled by the accelerator pedal, while at low transmission ratios, automatic control is preferred.

3. The system includes a clutch that connects the accelerator pedal directly to the throttle valve when manual control is desired, and the control unit can be programmed to generate pulses for controlling the stepper motor. The system also includes a logic sequencer and phase drivers for driving the stepper motor, and a simplified control unit using discrete components and an analog converter can be used to drive a DC motor. The invention is not limited to the particular system disclosed, but its scope is intended to be governed only by the scope of the appended claims.</summary>

1. The invention pertains to methods and apparatus for generating heat from particulate-laden gas or directly from waste fuels such as wood waste. This invention aims to provide a clean burning waste fuel burner that can deliver exhaust gases as clean as those produced by oil and gas burners.

2. Conventional wood waste fuel burners have been extremely inefficient in combustion, discharging undesirable amounts of gaseous and particulate pollution. These burners also cause depositions on the heat transfer tubes of the boiler, requiring frequent and expensive cleaning.

3. The invention provides a waste fuel burner that emits discharges of very minimal quantities of particulate materials within the levels permitted by local environmental regulations. The burner also operates producing little slag or clinkers.

4. The waste wood fuel burner can effectively burn wet wood of 70% moisture content (wet basis) and is self-regulating, easy to control, and has fast response times to changes in the load. The burner can also burn wood of nominal ash content and produces a residue that is free of clinkers.

5. The burner forms a conical pile of waste fuel, fed from below, with preheated underfire air percolating up through the pile in controlled amounts, drying and gasifying the waste fuel in the pile. The volatile gases driven off the pile are then partially oxidized by additional combustion air introduced tangentially.

6. The primary and secondary chambers can be added to any source of dirty particulate-laden combustible gas and effectively burn the gas to provide a source of useful heat and remove the particulate for meeting environmental emission standards. The primary chamber can be coupled directly to the exhaust of a coking operation for burning the gases and removing particulate from the exhaust.

7. The burner includes a primary combustion chamber having an internal side wall, a discharge opening, and a bottom, lined with refractory material spaced from an outer metallic shell by an air cooling passage. Fuel is fed from a hopper by a conveyor and is pushed into the form of a conical pile.

8. High pressure swirl air is admitted through tuyeres at an angle to the side wall, generating centrifugal forces that drive the heavier non-combusted materials to the outer wall while allowing the volatile gases to pass upward through the throat of the primary chamber. The tuyeres are individually adjustable to regulate the exact amount of air and velocity introduced into the primary combustion chamber.

9. The secondary chamber is provided with a side wall, a roof, an outlet, and

<summary>
1. The present invention is an evaporative refrigeration system that uses a heat exchanger to separate its dry and wet sides, keeping evaporating water separate from the useful air to achieve sensible cooling without adding water vapor to the useful air.
2. The system operates efficiently by drawing working air from the load, using a countercurrent flow of water and air in the heat exchanger, and can be further enhanced by incorporating a vapor compression refrigeration unit to dehumidify a portion of the cooled air stream.</summary>

1. The present invention relates to pumps, particularly to pumps for pumping fluids, and more specifically to a fluid pump capable of pumping fluids at high volumetric flow rate and high pressure. The pump comprises two or more pump heads configured in series, with each pump head having a housing containing an impeller driven by a drive structure. The housing of each pump head has an inlet through which fluid is drawn from outside the housing and at least two fluid conduits that combine into one fluid flow before exiting the pump head.

2. The pump heads are connected to provide rigidity and a fluid seal between the pump heads, and may be removably connected or formed in a unitary structure. The drive structure may comprise any one or collection of structures that is configured to impart rotational motion on the impellers. The motor may be, for example, an electric motor, a hydraulic motor, a combustion motor or any other motor that can be configured to drive the drive structure.

3. The fluid pump cannot be constructed by simply stacking known pumps together, as the initial and final pump heads have different design features to permit fluid flow from one pump head to the other while commonly driving the impellers. Intermediate pump heads have design features of both the initial and final pump heads to permit the intermediate pump heads to cooperate with neighboring pump heads. The pump heads may be connected to provide rigidity and a fluid seal between the pump heads.

4. A pump assembly comprises a fluid pump mounted on a support structure, which may comprise any suitable apparatus that permits operation of the pump at a fluid reservoir. The support structure may include a wheeled boom, a hitching assembly, and a trailer. The pump assembly may also include an elongated fluid conduit that carries pumped fluid from the fluid pump to a tank or some other fluid holding apparatus.

5. The fluid pump may be mounted on a wheeled boom, which comprises two sets of wheels mounted on the boom through a wheel frame proximate the first end of the boom. The boom may also include a towing hitch for securement to a vehicle for transporting the wheeled boom with the pump from location to location. An elongated fluid conduit extending between the first and second ends of the boom is in fluid communication with the outlet of the first pump head.

6. The fluid pump may also be mounted on a hitching assembly, which comprises a pump support on a first end of which the pump is mounted. A second end of the pump support is pivotally mounted on two arms, each of the two arms comprising

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to engine compression release brakes, specifically to engines having engine compression release brakes for less than all engine cylinders. This invention aims to overcome the problems associated with traditional engine compression release brake systems.

2. Traditional engine compression release brake systems typically include an engine brake for each engine cylinder, which can result in excess components if not all cylinders are used for braking. A reduction in engine components can improve the overall robustness of an engine.

3. The present invention provides an engine compression release brake system with a reduced number of components, where an engine compression release brake is provided for each of a portion of the engine cylinders, which is less than all of the plurality of engine cylinders. This system can be more efficient and cost-effective.

4. The engine compression release brake system includes a modular design, where each engine brake is operably coupled to a cam actuated exhaust valve. This design allows for easier installation and maintenance.

5. The engine includes an engine housing that defines a plurality of engine cylinders, and each cylinder has a movable piston that is movable between a retracted and an advanced position. The engine also includes a fuel injector and an exhaust valve for each cylinder.

6. The engine compression release brake includes a brake body, an electrical actuator, and a spool valve member that is movable between an upward and a downward position. The spool valve member controls the flow of high-pressure fluid to the exhaust valve actuator.

7. When the engine brake is activated, the spool valve member moves to its advanced position, allowing high-pressure fluid to flow to the exhaust valve actuator, which opens the exhaust valve and vents compressed air from the cylinder. This process provides engine braking.

8. The engine compression release brake system can be controlled by an electronic control module, which determines the desired braking horsepower and controls the activation of the engine brakes accordingly. The system can also be modified to include different types of compression release brakes.

9. The present invention provides a modular and efficient engine compression release brake system that can be customized to meet specific braking requirements, allowing customers to choose and pay for only the amount of braking horsepower they need. This system can be used in various engine applications, including diesel engines and homogeneous charge compression engines.

</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to support structures, specifically a mounting link between an engine structure and an attached structure such as an auxiliary gearbox. This mounting link is designed to withstand various loads, including routine vibrational loads and extreme shocks caused by hard landings or blade-off events.

2. Conventional gearboxes and gearbox connections are constructed to rigidly withstand all anticipated loads, often requiring additional material or being heavier to withstand extreme loads. However, this can lead to increased weight and mass, which may not be desirable in certain applications.

3. The invention includes a link assembly between an engine and a gearbox, comprising a male link, a female link, and a pin that selectively retains the male and female links. The female link receives the male link, allowing translation and forming a radial interface that dampens translation.

4. The link assembly can be part of a gearbox assembly that attaches to an engine, providing a medium to long link to connect the engine to an associated structure, such as the gearbox. The mounting link can rigidly constrain one degree of freedom between the engine and the gearbox.

5. In the event of extreme loads, the pin can shear, allowing the female and male links to translate relative to each other and absorb the shock. This helps prevent damage to the gearbox and its attached peripherals, while also preventing the gearbox from detaching from the engine.

6. The female and male links are in contact at the radial interface, which provides coulomb damping to dissipate energy created by the translation. The amount of coulomb damping is determined by the coefficient of friction, geometry, and contact areas of the female and male links.

7. The materials of the female and male links can be selected to provide the desired level of coulomb damping, and the damping force provided by the radial interface can be greater than or less than the force required to shear the pin. This allows for customization of the mounting link to suit specific applications.

8. A snap ring can be used to limit the relative travel of the male link within the female link, preventing the mounting link from separating after the pin is sheared. This ensures that the mounting link remains intact and functional even after experiencing extreme loads.

9. The use of the pin and coulomb damping provided by the radial interface eliminates the need for all linkages and peripheral connections to be capable of surviving extreme loads. This reduces the weight and mass of material required to adequately reinforce associated systems.

10. The mounting link can be easily maintained and repaired by replacing the pin with

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to archery equipment, specifically to apparatus and methods for attaching arrow points and nocks to arrow shafts and for balancing arrow shafts, providing a solution to the shortcomings of prior art.
2. The invention includes a point cap system that is small, lightweight, and adjustable in weight, allowing for perfect balance, as well as a balance pin whose weight can be adjusted to balance an arrow shaft.
3. The invention also provides means to attach points to arrow shafts without allowing dirt to enter the shaft, and utilizes the strength of unidirectional fiber reinforced shafts by reducing cross fiber stress at the end of the shaft.</summary>

1. The present invention relates to military weapons, specifically an electronically controlled pyrotechnic sound and flash simulator for use with small arms training. The simulator aims to provide a realistic simulation of small arms fire noise and flash without modifying the weapon.

2. The invention utilizes a low-cost plastic expendable housing a metal/oxidizer pyrotechnic in conjunction with an electrical ignition system. The expendable contains a plurality of rounds and is installed in a firing unit that can be inserted into the weapon via the magazine breech.

3. The electrical control circuit provides for automatic and semiautomatic fire, and interfaces with the weapon trigger and bolt. The circuitry consists of ten functional blocks, including a bolt interface, trigger interface, oscillator control, and firing control.

4. The firing control circuitry is designed to sequence through the pyrotechnic charges, triggering one charge at a time, and stopping when an unexpended charge is found. The circuitry also includes a firing sensor that detects when a charge fires and resets the oscillator control.

5. The small arms firing effect simulator is packaged to resemble the magazine clip of the M16 rifle, with a reusable housing that contains the electric control circuitry and the plastic expendable. The housing has an exhaust port that communicates with the ejection port of the M16 rifle.

6. The plastic expendable is designed to be fabricated in an automatic process, reducing cost, and contains a series of cups with pyrotechnic charges that are sealed with a plastic sealant. The charges are composed of a shaped pyrotechnic pellet that burns in a combination mode to produce a rapid increase in pressure, simulating small arms fire.

1. The present invention relates to an air intake device of an internal combustion engine that utilizes the dynamic effects of the air flow to improve the volumetric efficiency of the engine. The device comprises a tank providing a volumetric area extending along an intake tube, a valve disposed in an interconnecting portion between the tank and the intake passage, and valve activating means to open or shut the valve in response to the engine load. The arrangement makes it possible to enhance engine performance. However, it has been determined that there is an increase in the noise from the air intake if the inlet pipe upstream of the air cleaner is cut too short.

2. The object of the present invention is to provide an air intake device of an internal combustion engine that will improve the performance of the engine by the best utilization of the dynamic effect, to reduce noise from the air intake. According to the present invention, an intake device for an internal combustion engine having an air intake passage extending from an air cleaner to an intake manifold comprises a tank defining a volume, a first pipe defining a first passage interconnecting the tank with the air intake passage, and a second pipe defining a second passage interconnecting the tank with the air intake passage. The first and second passages are open to the intake passage at different locations with respect to each other, and the cross-sectional area of the second passage is smaller than that of the first passage. A valve is disposed in the first passage together with a valve actuating means responsive to an engine operating condition.

3. The preferred embodiment of the present invention includes a tank 4 providing a constant volume extended along the intake pipe 2, and two pipes 5 and 6 interconnecting the tank 4 with the intake pipe 2. The cross-sectional area of the pipe 5 is substantially equal to or larger than that of the intake pipe 2, and the pipe 6 is located upstream of the pipe 5 and has a smaller cross-sectional area than the pipe 5. A control valve 7 is disposed at the tank-side opening of the passage defined by pipe 5, and is actuated by an actuator 8 comprising a vacuum diaphragm actuator. The actuator 8 has a diaphragm 8a mounted in a casing 8b, and the valve 7 is fixed to the diaphragm 8a by a valve rod 8c.

4. The operation of the valve 7 is controlled based on the engine speed and load, and the valve 7 is preferably closed

<summary>
1. The invention is a two-part mounting bracket assembly that allows for simple and effective mounting of equipment, such as speakers or other objects, to a variety of surfaces, including poles, walls, and columns. The assembly consists of a stationary bracket and an adjustable bracket that can be easily connected and secured together without requiring additional tools or hardware.

2. The bracket assembly is designed for one-person installation and provides 360 degrees of horizontal adjustment, as well as vertical adjustment from 0 to -70 degrees, allowing for precise directional positioning of the mounted object. The assembly is also resistant to weather, wind, and vibration, making it suitable for outdoor use, and can be used with a variety of objects, including loudspeakers, lighting, signage, displays, monitors, and video cameras.</summary>

1. The present disclosure relates to a combustion apparatus, specifically a burner that can be part of a system including a plurality of interchangeable or modular heat utilizing appliances.
2. The burner is designed to optimize efficiency and limit unburned fuel emissions, and features a combustion chamber with a fuel holder, air inlets, and a shroud to support secondary and tertiary combustion.
3. The burner has a modular design, allowing for the attachment of various heat utilizing appliances, such as cookers, a food smoker, a space heater, and a pyrolyzer, using manual couplings.
4. The burner also features a pivotally coupled ash pan, a perforate food grate, and a cover to prevent inadvertent ingress of objects and emission of live embers.
5. The system can be used for various applications, including cooking, smoking, space heating, and pyrolysis, and can be modified and combined in various ways to achieve different functionalities.</summary>

<summary>
1. The rotary internal combustion engine's water cooling system plays a crucial role in achieving fuel economy and durability, particularly in the area surrounding the spark plugs where combustion and expansion of working gases occur.
2. The in-line arrangement of spark plugs in a rotary engine creates a mechanism that disrupts the flow of cooling fluid, collects vapor films, and prevents heat extraction in critical areas.
3. The invention aims to provide an ignition and cooling system combination that maintains efficient combustion while improving cooling characteristics to reduce the possibility of structural failure of the engine's housing.
4. The housing structure is designed to facilitate circumferential cooling flow in the rotor housing while permitting the intrusion of spark plug bosses, minimizing thermal distortion, particularly in the zone surrounding the spark plug bosses.
5. The invention employs a staggered arrangement of spark plug bosses, which promotes a relatively close in-line arrangement of the spark plug terminals while allowing for a controlled flow regime between the bosses.
6. The staggered configuration of the spark plug bosses enables high-velocity flow therethrough, devoid of uncontrolled swirling eddies, maintaining a high heat transfer coefficient at the sensitive spark plug boss surfaces.
7. Tests have shown that the staggered spark plug configuration increases the heat transfer coefficient between the flow and bosses by as much as 44% compared to the "in-line" arrangement.
8. The invention provides a housing structure for a rotary internal combustion engine that employs circumferential cooling, increasing the heat transfer coefficient of the cooling circuit at the spark plug boss zone by at least 20% over prior art capabilities.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to turbines and a method of minimizing flow disturbance caused by the closing and reopening of turbine control valves during periodic operational testing. The method uses control valve positions as feedback to minimize such flow disturbance. This is achieved by maintaining the total mass flow through several parallel turbine inlet flow control valves constant, which in turn maintains the steam generator pressure constant. The inlet pressure regulator is unaffected during inlet control valve testing.

2. The flow is determined as a function of control valve position, i.e., valve stem lift. The flow change due to closure of one of the several parallel flow paths during valve testing results in a change to the system that is controlling pressure from N valves to N-1 valves. The flow characteristic for each valve of the system with N valves, and for the system with N-1 valves, is determined during the turbine design process. The flow characteristics are based on total flow and individual valve stem lift.

3. The test compensation circuit uses control valve positions as feedback and compensates by adjusting the flow through parallel control valves to minimize flow disturbance caused by the closure and reopening of turbine control valve during testing. The circuit includes a test compensation array, a sample and hold circuit, a multiplier circuit, and a summing circuit. The test compensation array provides the mass flow difference demanded by the TCV reference for the three input control valves not being tested. The sample and hold circuit receives a signal indicating whether the particular input valve is in test mode.

4. The multiplier circuit receives the output of the test compensation array and a second signal indicating the amount of flow compensation needed for the three valves not under test. The output of the multiplier circuit is fed into a select circuit, which determines whether the output of the multiplier circuit or a reference signal with a constant value of "0" is fed into the summing circuit. The summing circuit sums the output of the select circuit with the TCV reference signal and feeds it into a flow lift array that determines the valve lift of the valve being controlled. The logic of the test control circuit is such that the select circuit will output the value of the multiplier circuit only when a valve other than itself is being tested.

5. The method and system of the present invention were tested using a mathematically modeled, thermodynamically accurate, and simulated turbine system. The control system contained the algorithms for compensation of flow during valve testing. The use of the control valve test compensating control of the present invention reduced the pressure excursion of the turbine inlet main steam pressure by 95

1. The invention relates to a mixing valve for an aircraft cleaning apparatus that combines fluids from two separate sources into one mixture. The valve has two inlets, A and B, and one outlet, with the outlet mixture ranging from 0% inlet A fluid, 100% inlet B fluid to 100% inlet A fluid, 0% inlet B fluid. The valve is designed to provide a constant pressure cleaning solution to each user, with the cleaning agent to water ratio continuously adjustable. This allows multiple users to accomplish specific cleaning tasks without disrupting other team members.

2. The mixing valve has a valve body with a first inlet passage for receiving a first fluid at a first predetermined pressure and a second inlet passage for receiving a second fluid at a second predetermined pressure. The valve body also has an outlet passage for providing a proportional mixture of the two fluids. A valve means is disposed within the body for directing the two fluids toward the outlet passage. The valve means is adjustable to permit the mixture to range between a proportion of about 0% first fluid, 100% second fluid to about 100% second fluid, 0% first fluid.

3. The valve system includes a flow restricting device for reducing the flow rate of fluid from the first inlet passage to the valve body. The flow restricting device has a threaded portion and a flow restricting bore disposed therethrough. The device is preferably a screw made from 316 S/S, with a torques-type head and a bore approximately 0.052 inches in diameter. The flow restricting device is not restricted to a single bore diameter, and other flow restriction rates are contemplated.

4. The valve system also includes an elongated valve member with a cylindrical portion having a bore extending therethrough perpendicular to the longitudinal axis of the valve. A sealing sleeve has a pair of perpendicularly intersecting bores extending therethrough, with one bore sized slightly smaller than the diameter of the cylindrical portion. The sleeve is preferably made of TEFLON and is somewhat elastic to allow stretching over the cylindrical portion. The valve member further includes a cylindrical portion for receiving a seal carrier, which has a bore sized to receive the cylindrical portion therethrough.

5. The seal carrier has a boss sized to contact a surface of the cylindrical portion, compressing the sleeve against the walls of the valve body. The seal carrier also defines a recess sized to house a nut disposed therein, with a threaded portion of the cylindrical portion engaging the complementarily threaded bore of the nut. <summary>
1. The present invention relates to a method of compressing gas in a compressor station for a gas pipeline, particularly in permanent frost areas, where the gas is compressed to a higher pressure, cooled by heat exchange, and then expanded to the desired exit pressure and temperature.
2. The invention also relates to an arrangement for carrying out the method, which includes at least one compressor, a heat exchanger, valve-controlled pipelines, and control units, with an electronic control that operates the compressor to compress the gas to an excess pressure and then expands it to the desired exit pressure.
3. The method and arrangement of the present invention provide a more efficient and cost-effective way of cooling the gas, especially during warmer periods, by utilizing the physical effect of cooling a compressed gas when expanded to a lower pressure, either by throttling or with the simultaneous performance of work.
4. The invention offers several advantages over conventional re-cooling technology, including lower investment costs, reduced risk of accidents, and increased availability of the overall plant, making it a more attractive solution for compressor stations in gas pipelines.</summary>

1. Electronic components produce heat during operation, and in some cases, free convection cooling is not sufficient to prevent overheating. In such cases, electric fans are often used to move ambient air across the components at a higher rate. This method is a low-cost solution for keeping electronic components within acceptable temperature ranges.

2. Cooling fans are often integrated with an enclosure that houses the electronic components, and the fan is typically mounted to the enclosure using fasteners such as screws or rivets. However, this method increases the product cost due to labor and tool requirements. The handling costs associated with fasteners also add to the overall expense.

3. The present invention discloses a system for eliminating fasteners used to secure cooling fans to an enclosure. This system can be utilized in various applications, including the automotive, computer, and electronic instrumentation industries. The invention is applicable in any industry where forced air movement is used as a temperature controlling medium.

4. The cooling fan assembly of the present invention includes a motor, a fan blade, and a motor carrier with mounting legs. The motor carrier is coupled to the motor housing, which houses the operative components of the motor. The motor carrier includes spring members that urge the motor carrier away from the panel once the mounting legs are in their fully seated position.

5. The panel includes recess portions that correspond to each of the mounting legs, and each recess portion has an opening with an enlarged opening region and a residual opening region. The turned-out portions of the mounting legs are sized to fit into the enlarged opening region without restriction. The height of the turned-out portions is less than or equal to the height of the recessed portion.

6. To install the cooling fan assembly, it is brought adjacent to the panel, and the turned-out portions of the mounting legs are inserted into the enlarged opening region. A combined compressive and rotating force is then applied to move the assembly into the partially installed position. The compressive force compresses the spring member, and the rotating force repositions the resilient legs into an intermediate sized opening.

7. As the cooling fan assembly is further rotated, the resilient leg portions enter into the residual opening, which is sized smaller than the enlarged opening but not as small as the intermediate opening. The leg portions spring outwardly, capturing each pair within its associated residual opening. The spring member remains in a compressed state, urging the turned-out portions against the exterior surface of the panel and preventing vibrational noise and forces from causing the leg portions to "back out" of their respective openings

<summary>

1. The invention aims to provide kinematic mounts with novel damping features to protect instruments from potentially damaging flight loads. The mounts are designed to incorporate a passive energy dissipating mechanism, which can be applied to a large number of precision or optical instruments/sensors where alignment stability is important. The device can be used to minimize loads transmitted to the mounted instrument during launch.

2. The kinematic mounts have been modified by inserting vibration damping materials into the mounts, which introduce a damping mechanism into the six mount suspension modes. The damping mechanism may be provided at machined hinge or flexure locations of the mounts, and can be designed in various ways, including the use of spherical dampers or cylindrical slot dampers. These designs can be tailored to achieve specific bending stiffness characteristics.

3. The spherical damper design uses a viscoelastic material that deforms in shear, dissipating vibration energy in the form of heat, while the cylindrical slot damper design uses o-rings that are subjected to tensile or compressive forces. The use of these damping materials can result in significant levels of damping, with the six suspension modes being damped by as much as 10% of critical modal damping. This can lead to a significant performance improvement over the design without the damping treatment.

4. The invention also proposes a mounting scheme that uses six identical strut elements, which can be arranged in a variety of configurations to provide a kinematic mounting system. The use of truss structures can provide efficient stiffness to weight ratios, and the design can be simplified by using a single strut design. The proposed mounting concept also allows for the six suspension vibration modes of the instrument to become approximately uncoupled, which can be beneficial in applications where dynamic disturbances are inherent within the instrument.</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a large size clutch unit of the oil shear type, particularly for use in an aircraft catapult system, which overcomes the disadvantages of previously known constructions by providing strong coupling forces between plates and discs while maintaining high control accuracy.
2. The clutch unit comprises an input shaft, an output shaft, clutch plates connected to one shaft, and clutch discs connected to the other shaft, with separate piston and cylinder means for closing the gap between each disc and its adjacent plates.
3. The unit utilizes hydraulic fluid for the dual purpose of retracting the plate actuating means to reduce residual drag and as a coolant for the clutch discs, and allows for replacement of portions of the clutch discs without requiring complete disassembly of the unit.
4. The invention provides a new and improved clutch unit with highly improved cooling, minimum disc friction, and convenient inspection of disc segments, and minimizes residual drag, making it suitable for high-capacity applications such as an 85,000 horsepower clutch operating at 1200 RPM.</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention relates to an internal combustion engine that incorporates a combustion cylinder and one or more expansion cylinders to increase thermal efficiency and reduce heat loss. The expansion cylinders are designed to capture the heat energy from the exhaust gases and convert it into mechanical energy. This is achieved by injecting water into the expansion cylinders, which vaporizes and expands, driving the piston and contributing to the overall torque output. The use of multiple expansion cylinders allows for a greater surface area and volumetric displacement, enabling the engine to capture more heat energy.

2. The engine design also includes a gearing system that allows the expansion cylinders to operate at a different speed than the combustion cylinder, optimizing the output and reducing heat loss. The gearing system can be a two-to-one gear reduction or a more complex planetary transmission. The engine can also include a water cooling system that captures heat from the combustion cylinder and transfers it to the expansion cylinders, increasing the temperature of the injected water and allowing for more efficient energy conversion. This system can be a closed circuit with a pump and heat exchanger or a passive system with a sealed container.

3. The invention also includes a water recovery system that captures and recycles the water used in the engine, reducing the need for a large water tank. The system includes a water scrubber or water trap that returns water to the tank, and a pump that drives the water back into the engine. The engine can also include catalytic materials on the surfaces of the cylinders, pistons, and valves to reduce exhaust emissions. The use of these materials can eliminate the need for a separate catalytic converter, further increasing the efficiency of the engine.</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to the fabrication of plates or blanks of coated steel intended to be welded and then heat-treated to obtain parts having good mechanical characteristics and good corrosion resistance. The invention concerns the elimination of a precise portion of the metal coating on either side of the joint before welding to solve problems of localized corrosion and the formation of intermetallic areas. The inventors have shown that eliminating a portion of the coating solves the problems referred to above. The width of the area from which the metal alloy layer has been removed must be adjusted to enable welding with no introduction of any element of the precoat into the molten area.

2. The precoat is preferably an aluminum alloy or aluminum-based, and the metal alloy of the precoat can contain 8 to 11% by weight of silicon and 2 to 4% of iron, the remainder consisting of aluminum and inevitable impurities. The layer of intermetallic alloy is topped by a metal alloy layer, and the periphery of the plate has a portion that does not carry the metal alloy layer but retains the intermetallic alloy layer. This portion is intended to be placed in contact with another plate and then to be butt-welded in a plane defined by the edge to form a blank. The width of the area from which the metal layer has been removed must be between 0.2 and 2.2 mm.

3. The removal of the metal layer can be monitored by means of micrographic examination or optical inspection, and the efficiency of the removal operation can be checked quickly by spectrometer reflectivity or emissivity measurement. The area from which the metal alloy has been removed can be produced by partly eliminating the metal alloy layer on at least one precoated face of the plate by brushing or by means of a laser beam. The width of the area from which the metal alloy has been removed and which is not totally contiguous with the periphery of the plate can be between 0.4 and 30 mm. The precoating is preferably effected by dip coating with aluminum.

4. The steel strip was precoated by dipping it in a molten bath of an aluminum alloy containing 9.3% of silicon and 2.8% of iron, the remainder consisting of aluminum and inevitable impurities. The strip was then cut into plates with a format of 300×500 mm2, and these have on each face a precoat comprising a layer of intermetallic alloy comprising mostly Fe2Al3, Fe2Al5, and

<summary>
1. The present invention is a continuation of U.S. patent application Ser. No. 11/942,576, filed Nov. 19, 2007, and is generally in the field of supervisory control and data acquisition systems for energy extracting vessel navigation.
2. The invention is embodied in a remote control system for operation and navigation of a mobile structure that optimally recovers energy from an offshore marine environment.
3. The system includes a control and communications microprocessor system, a central service facility with a server and workstations, and various sensors and control circuits for inputting and outputting variables to the SCADA control algorithm.
4. The system uses weather satellite data, GPS, and other sources of weather information to track the position and velocity of the mobile structure and optimize energy extraction.
5. The SCADA system includes a graphical user interface (GUI) that allows remote humans to interact with the system and choose mission critical navigation plans.
6. The GUI displays various information, including position, heading, velocity, and points of sail for the mobile structure, as well as virtual reality representations of the vessel's attitude and surroundings.
7. The system uses a Velocity Prediction Program (VPP) to estimate or forecast energy efficiency and perform least-cost or highest yield path analysis.
8. The system also includes an advanced physical object detection, identification, and avoidance system that uses radar, sonar, and video camera data to detect and avoid obstacles.
9. The system is designed to operate in severe weather patterns, such as hurricanes or typhoons, and can be used for logistics-only purposes or for energy extraction in environments that are hazardous to human crews.</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a rolling body guide cage produced from at least one ring element and several guide structures arranged in succession in the circumferential direction. The ring element is composed of at least two flat material ring segments joined to one another in succession in the circumferential direction. These ring segments are connected, in particular welded, to one another in a production step preceding the formation of the axial profiling.

2. The invention aims to reduce production costs by minimizing cutting waste during the manufacture of rolling body guide cages. This is achieved by using flat material ring segments that are joined together to form a ring element. The ring segments are cut out from a sheet metal material, reducing waste and saving material.

3. The flat material ring segments are preferably cut out as 120° ring segments, requiring only three weld points to join together a ring element. These segments can be punched out in close succession from a sheet metal strip, allowing for efficient production. The circular arc-like inner and outer edges, as well as the joint geometries, can be cut out in one step.

4. The ring segments are connected to one another via joint contours that engage positively in one another, forming an undercut geometry that preliminarily couples the ring segments to one another in the circumferential direction. The geometric profile of the joint contours is selected to produce adequate coupling of the ring segments. The joint contours are configured to taper both towards the ring element inner circumferential edge and towards the ring element outer circumferential edge with as obtuse an angle as possible.

5. The ring segments can be produced with a slight oversize and further cut and calibrated after welding in a contouring step. Alternatively, the ring segments can be cut to their final dimensions in terms of their material width and subsequently only formed and punched internally. The ring segments can be punched out from a sufficiently wide strip material and pushed directly into a positioning device.

6. The invention is suitable for the manufacture of radial bearing cages and axial bearing cages, including cages for groove and angular ball bearings. The rolling body guide cage can be structured such that it is composed of a first ring element and a structurally identical second ring element positioned in mirror-symmetry. The per se structurally identical ring elements are preferably put together such that the weld points formed between the ring segments of the ring elements of both ring elements are offset with respect to one another in the circumferential direction.

7. The method for manufacturing a rolling body guide cage involves composing a ring element from at least

<summary>
1. The present methods and systems relate to processing and transmitting information to facilitate providing service in a telecommunications network, particularly using global satellite positioning to facilitate processing and transmission of information associated with telecommunications service locations and routing travel between more than one such service location. The methods and systems aim to acquire information associated with a customer's service location, such as latitude and longitude coordinates, to enable efficient identification of the service location. This information can be used to update databases and provide directions for a service technician traveling between customer service locations.

2. The system includes a technician input device, a technician server, a global positioning satellite system, a dispatch system, an address guide system, and a customer records system. The GPS system serves to acquire information associated with a customer service location, including latitude and longitude coordinates, and the mapping system provides travel or routing directions to a service technician from a first location to at least a second location where customer service is to be performed. The system enables accurate and efficient customer service by providing supervisors and managers with comprehensive technician activity information and enhancing response time for addressing customer service needs.</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields, particularly magnetic fields, using two sensors and a digital processor. The system aims to compensate both homogeneous and inhomogeneous magnetic fields. It also simulates measuring electromagnetic interfering fields at the location of the object to be protected.

2. The system consists of two real triaxial magnetic field sensors, three pairs of compensation coils, and a control unit. The control unit is preferably a digital signal processor or a field-programmable gate array. The system protects an object against the influences of an interfering field.

3. The six output signals of the two real sensors are combined to form three output signals of a virtual sensor through a freely definable kind of averaging. The averaging algorithm is chosen to represent the amplitude of the interfering field at the location of the object to be protected. The averaging takes place in the control system.

4. The control system receives the six output signals of the two real magnetic field sensors via six inputs and processes them according to a specific algorithm. The algorithm involves matrix multiplications and the use of a control operator. The control operator can be a matrix or a nonlinear algorithm.

5. The system can be used with a single compensation system or with two compensation systems operated directly beside each other. In the latter case, feedback effects between the two systems are accounted for using a 6x6 back coupling matrix. The matrix computationally eliminates the parts of the signals that are crosstalks from an output signal to a virtual signal.

6. The system can generate homogeneous or inhomogeneous compensation fields depending on the nature of the interfering field. If the interfering field is inhomogeneous, it is not purposeful to generate a homogeneous compensation field. In this case, a single actuator coil can be used instead of a pair of Helmholtz coils.

7. The system can be used with different types of coils, including Helmholtz coils and single actuator coils. The coils can be connected in series, in parallel, or depending on the impedance. The system can also be used with different types of sensors, including triaxial magnetic field sensors.

8. The control unit of the system can be designed to operate in different modes, including broadband, selective concerning a frequency range, or selective concerning a frequency. The control unit can also be designed to use different control algorithms, including linear and nonlinear algorithms.

9. The system can be used in various applications, including imaging systems using magnetic fields, such as scanning electron microscopes

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a method for investigating a sample derived from a biological source using CARS microscopy, where a resonance signal generated by coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering is sensed in image-producing fashion, and at least one resonance site is furnished by means of a bioorthogonal reaction of an intrinsic chemical structure of the sample with at least one reaction partner.
2. The method allows for the introduction of resonance sites into a sample that does not inherently possess them, enabling the detection of target sites in any samples without negatively affecting biochemical processes, and providing a reproducible counter-staining of the non-resonant background in the context of CARS microscopy.</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention provides a system for assessing segmentations from various sources, such as comparing a "gold standard" segmentation approved by a clinician against segmentations provided by clinicians in training or different software systems.
2. The system accepts electronic files, such as DICOM-RT standard files, as inputs, converts the segmentations to volume models, and compares the volume models to identify missing and extra volume elements.
3. The system measures and optionally weights the missing and extra volume elements according to their distance from the reference volume elements to produce an output indicating the quality of one segmentation with respect to the other.
4. The invention can be used for periodic quality assurance of autosegmentation routines or evaluation of those routines when they are updated or used with new imaging technology.
5. The system uses an electronic computer executing a stored program to receive electronic files, generate volume models, compare the volume models, and output a measure of conformance between the three-dimensional surfaces circumscribing the structure.
6. The system allows users to define a metric method, such as a combination of constant, linear, and exponential functions, to evaluate the quality of segmentations.
7. The system displays a graphical representation of the conformance of the segmentations, including a histogram showing cumulative missing and extra volume elements as a function of distance ranges.
8. The system provides a quantitative evaluation of the comparison of the two segmentations, including primary volume, secondary volume, missing volume, extra volume, and metric method/metric score.
9. The present invention can be used in various applications, including training clinicians, periodic quality assurance testing, assessing anatomy auto-segmentation routines, and evaluating changes in internal anatomy during radiation therapy.</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to data processing systems, specifically to the apparatus for executing floating point operations, and aims to accelerate the effective subtraction operation in a floating point unit.
2. The effective subtraction operation is complex and time-consuming, involving steps such as aligning fractions, subtracting, normalizing, and rounding, which can be accelerated by dividing the operation into two procedures based on the absolute value of the difference in the arguments of the exponents.
3. When the absolute value of the difference in the arguments of the exponents is greater than one, the subtraction operation can be performed to ensure a positive resultant quantity, reducing the number of steps required.
4. When the absolute value of the difference in the arguments of the exponents is less than or equal to one, the alignment of the fractions can be performed without requiring a separate step, and either the normalization or rounding step can be omitted.
5. The invention uses a difference between a subset of signals of the operand exponent arguments to accelerate the effective subtraction operation, allowing the subtraction of differences between operand fractions to begin before the complete difference between the operand exponent arguments is determined.
6. The subset difference is used to initiate the correct procedure for determining the final fraction result, which can be either the result of the subtraction operation or one of the operand fractions, depending on the value of the complete difference between the operand exponent arguments.
7. The apparatus implementing the invention includes a subtraction unit, detection logic unit, shift and selection logic unit, and selection logic unit, which work together to accelerate the effective subtraction operation and determine the final fraction result.</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to the collection of blood and medical specimens in a medical facility, aiming to reduce or avoid mislabeling of specimen vials. The invention provides a method and system for tracking a specimen acquired from a patient.

2. The prior art method of collecting a specimen involves a medical professional placing an order, which is then entered into a computer, and barcode labels are printed and applied to specimen vials. However, this method is known to result in mislabeling of specimen vials.

3. The invention uses a software program that executes on one or more standalone or networked computers, coupled to a local or remote computer storage, to store and process data. The software program can be stored in computer storage or a portable computer storage.

4. The method of collecting a specimen in accordance with the present invention involves a medical professional placing an order, which is then entered into the computer, and a unique order barcode number is generated and stored in a relational manner with the patient's information. The patient's ID band includes a unique patient barcode number, which is input into the computer.

5. The processor determines if a database data structure exists that includes the patient's barcode number and order barcode number, and if so, stores the barcode number on the badge of the blood drawer and each vial barcode number in a relational manner. If not, the method advances to correct any discrepancy in the relationship between the patient's barcode number and the order barcode number.

6. The processor causes a signal to be output that informs the blood drawer to draw the blood sample and send it to a lab for analysis, and starts a timer to determine if the blood draw is completed within a predetermined time. The processor stores an indication of the completion of the blood draw in a relational manner with the patient's information and barcode numbers.

7. The invention provides a means of achieving a failsafe, zero-defect process for identifying and processing patient specimen samples, eliminating the cost of vial labels, associated printers, and staff labor. The invention can be implemented in any suitable manner utilizing one or more standalone or networked computers and local or remote computer storage.

</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention is a voice-activated distance measuring device that provides distance and other information to a golfer. It uses voice recognition technology and GPS technology to provide data on the golf course and its parameters in a verbal, electronically spoken form. The device can be incorporated into an article of clothing, such as a golf hat or visor. It may also use distance measuring technology such as infrared, optics, Doppler acoustics, and the like.

2. The device uses commercially available GPS data to convert GPS mapped longitude and latitude coordinates to measure distance and other factors. It may use any GPS system available to measure the longitude and latitude coordinates to compute the distance and other golf course parameters. The device incorporates voice recognition technology to accept voice commands from the user, which are sensed by a voice sensor. The device responds to voice commands such as "distance," "pin-placement," or any other such word or words.

3. The device incorporates voice synthesis technology to provide an audible output by electronically produced spoken words, to provide distance and other information to the user via a loudspeaker or headphone. The output acoustics can be adjusted for volume level and frequency filtered for any particular user requirement or application. The device may also provide other information such as the green size, pin placement, and other information on the golf course parameters. The GPS and voice recognition electronics may be incorporated into any design of headgear, such as a hat or visor.

4. The device may accept verbal or any other data input and memorize and compute this, when prompted by voice command or an electrical pulse generated by touch or remote control, to predict golf course user golf strategy, club selection, rules, and other golf player needs. The GPS technology determines the actual distance traveled by the ball and its accuracy. Information regarding weather conditions, such as wind speed and wind direction, may also be provided. Over time, the device may build a library of information regarding the golfer's personal shot results.

5. The device may be used to provide pre-recorded golf instructions to assist the golfer in making a specified golf shot, when prompted to do so by a voice recognition command. The device may be used for such applications as hiking, surveyors, and hunters, and other applications. The device may also be used for scuba divers using an underwater design which may use any latitude and longitude measurement technology. The device may be expanded to include its use in any portable application.

6. The device may be provided with a communications method, such as but

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to the field of semiconductor design technology, specifically to systems and techniques used for implementing circuit designs into silicon-based integrated circuits (ICs).
2. The invention aims to provide a design rule checking system and method that accurately reports errors for different regions in a system, such as memory and logic circuits.
3. The method involves creating customized design rules for each type of region by modifying a standard set of logic rules to reflect the needs of particular regions in the chip.
4. The customized design rules are based on pushing more liberal parameters onto stricter parameters contained in the standard logic rules, and only in circumstances where it is necessary to do so.
5. The invention uses a design rule checker to check different areas of an IC layout against the customized design rules, resulting in a design rule check result that includes separate error reports for layout violations detected in each region.
6. The invention can be applied to any mask pattern database, including one having no memory blocks or multiple types of memory blocks, and can be implemented using conventional GDS formatted data.
7. The invention ensures that all types of memory regions fulfill all memory rules of their group, and all logic regions fulfill logic and memory rules, avoiding false errors and making the process more reliable and efficient.</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention relates to the use of waveguide holograms as illuminators for objects with specific illumination requirements, such as display holograms or spatial light modulators. The illumination system comprises a thin substrate waveguide optically coupled to a coherent light source, such as a laser. This system provides extremely high diffraction efficiencies and can be used to illuminate objects in a controlled fashion. The waveguide hologram can be recorded non-uniformly to compensate for non-uniformity of the diffracted wavefront.

2. The waveguide hologram illuminator has several advantages over conventional lens illumination systems, including compactness, ruggedness, and reduced reflection losses. The active volume of the waveguide hologram illuminator is much smaller than that of a conventional lens illumination system. The diffraction efficiency of the waveguide hologram illuminator can approach 0.99, and the absence of stray light propagating forward to the observer is a significant advantage. The undiffracted light from the waveguide hologram illuminator is trapped in the waveguide.

3. However, there are some penalties associated with the use of waveguide hologram illuminators, including critical alignment of the laser beam and a time delay across the hologram. The non-uniformity of the diffracted wavefront along the propagation direction is inevitable unless combated. The waveguide hologram tends to produce two diffracted beams, one out of each side, which can reduce the useful efficiency and introduce noise into the system. Light dispersion can also occur if the input and output angles are not equal or opposite.

4. The problem of illumination depletion can be compensated for a priori or a posteriori. A posteriori compensation involves exposing a photographic emulsion to the uncompensated beam, which absorbs most where the beam is brightest and uniformizes the wavefront passing through it. The a priori approach records the hologram non-uniformly so that the reconstructed beam is uniform. For extremely high uniformity, a priori compensation can be followed by a posteriori compensation.

5. The problem of two-sidedness can be solved by absorbing the light emerging from one side, placing a mirror on one side to reflect all of the light into the same direction, or using off-axis illumination. When illuminating spatial light modulators, new possibilities arise, such as diffracting out only polarized light and using the SLM to modulate the polarization. Polarization analyzers can be used to control or block the unmodulated light.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a method and apparatus for testing squirrel cage rotors of dynamoelectric machines, such as electric motors and generators, to obtain the resistance, reactance, and effective electrical skew of the rotor. The apparatus comprises a test head for accepting and causing relative angular movement between the rotor and test head, exciting means for magnetizing the rotor, voltage sensing means for generating a voltage signal, and current sensing means for sensing the magnitude of the alternating current. The processing means determines the resistance and reactance of the rotor responsive to the voltage signal and current signal.

2. The test apparatus includes a data acquisition, processing and control system that controls testing and acquires data from each test head independently. The system automatically performs the rotor test on the respective test fixture, controls the rotation of the rotor, and processes the acquired data without further operator intervention. The system also provides automatic pass/fail determinations and statistical comparison and evaluation of the measurement results.

3. The test head includes a set of primary windings that form at least one pair of poles, a voltage sensing pick-up coil, and a skew sensing pick-up coil located at one end of the test head structure. The voltage pick-up coil produces a voltage signal representative of the voltage induced in the rotor, while the skew pick-up coil senses flux build-up at the end of the rotor due to the rotor's effective skew. The test head also includes a current sensor that senses the current provided to energize the test head.

4. The data processor acquires 32 samples in a cycle of the exciting alternating current, then ignores samples for the next five cycles, and samples again for 32 samples, repeating this pattern for a total of forty sampling cycles. The processor multiplies each current sample by the corresponding voltage sample to obtain a power value, and processes the 32 samples of the voltage signal, current signal, skew signal, and power value to obtain four test values. The control processor then determines a mean resistance, reactance, and effective skew for the rotor from the 40 test values, as well as the range of the 40 values for the resistance and the effective skew.</summary>

<summary>
1. The present disclosure provides a method for securing a mobile device by granting access to native resources of an operating system to a managed library in response to validating a digital certificate associated with the managed library.
2. The method also denies access to native resources of the operating system to a managed application, which includes a digital certificate authorizing the managed application to access a specific native resource of the operating system through the managed library.
3. The disclosure further provides a method for receiving a request from a managed application to access a native system resource through a managed library, and authorizing the request by a manager that includes information identifying managed libraries that the managed application is authorized to access.
4. The method also includes verifying managed metadata associated with an executable, inspecting the managed metadata at runtime to determine that the executable includes type-safe code, and storing the verified executable in a digitally signed container.
5. The disclosure provides a secure way for third-party applications to execute on a mobile device while protecting the device's native resources and preventing malicious attacks.</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to an improved identification card containing an internal antenna and integrated circuit chip laminated between two protective, non-rigid layers onto which artwork may be printed, which are then laminated between two rigid outer layers. This design protects the electronic components from damage and provides a low-cost, easily constructed identification card. The card differs from prior art in that it uses relatively shock-absorbing layers to disseminate external forces over a broad area, thus protecting the electronic components.

2. The identification card comprises a core layer, an antenna fixed to the core layer, a computer chip electrically connected to the antenna, and a bottom sheet attached to the core layer by an adhesive layer. The core layer and bottom sheet are then encased between two laminate layers, which provide mechanical strength to the image-receiving layer and hence to the image(s) in the finished document. The laminate layers are formed from an amorphous or biaxially oriented polyester or other optically clear plastic.

3. The identification card may have one or more image-receiving layers, which are formed from any material capable of receiving an image by dye diffusion thermal transfer or ink-jet printing. A protective layer is affixed over at least the portion of the image-receiving layer carrying the second indicia, serving to protect the relatively fragile image-receiving layer from damage and prevent bleeding of dye from the image-receiving layer. The protective layer may include security features such as a low cohesivity polymeric layer, security ink, or other security features that protect the document against tampering or counterfeiting.</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to the implementation of a memory, specifically a queue, particularly a FIFO-type queue, in a memory, intended for use in connection with functional memories.
2. In functional memories, updates are carried out by copying the path from the root of a tree-shaped structure to the point of updating, and then making the update in the copied data, also known as "copy-on-write".
3. The invention aims to reduce the amount of required copying in a functional structure by implementing a queue using a tree-shaped structure with nodes of a given maximum size.
4. Additions of data units are directed to the first non-full node on the first edge of the data structure, and deletions are directed to a leaf node on the edge of the tree.
5. The tree-shaped data structure is balanced, meaning all leaf nodes are at the same level, and all internal nodes are full, except for those on the left or right edge of the tree.
6. The invention uses a header node with three elements, each containing a pointer to a separate node constituting the end, middle, or beginning of the queue.
7. The header node allows for faster and less space-consuming updates, as additions require a constant time independent of the length of the queue.
8. The invention also includes a bit indicating which edge of the header node constitutes the end and which the beginning of the FIFO queue, allowing for inversion of the queue in constant time and space.
9. The queue can be used as a double-ended queue, allowing for additions to the beginning and deletions from the end of the queue.
10. The invention can be implemented in a memory arrangement with a header node, comprising an actual memory, intermediate registers, control logic, a flag register, an input register, and an output register.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention provides practical methods to build embedded EPROM devices using existing IC manufacture technologies, allowing for the integration of EPROM devices with DRAM or logic circuits on the same wafer without additional manufacturing cost.
2. The invention also introduces a novel type of EPROM device called "stress effect programmable read only memory" (SEPROM) that uses the damages caused by electrical stresses on common transistors to store data, making it ideal for embedded applications and security purposes.</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a technique for easily and quickly determining the optimum value of feedback gain used for calculating correction amount in feedback control. This technique is particularly useful in applications such as moving an automatic guidance vehicle along a predetermined course.

2. The prior art method of determining feedback gain, known as the limit sensitivity process, involves gradually increasing the P gain until self-sustaining vibration is obtained, and then determining the optimum values of the P, I, and D gains based on the value of the P gain at this time. However, this method has problems in detecting the self-sustaining vibration and may not be suitable for all types of control subjects.

3. The present invention provides a method of determining feedback gain that permits determining the proper value of feedback gain both easily and accurately, in a short period of time and irrespective of the kind of the subject of control. This method involves provisionally determining a predetermined value of a feedback gain, executing feedback control, detecting an error, calculating an evaluation value, and repeating these steps to calculate a feedback gain value that provides a suitable evaluation value.

4. In the method of the present invention, the evaluation value is calculated based on the error detected during the execution of feedback control, and the feedback gain value is calculated based on the relation between the feedback gain value and the evaluation value. This method allows for the determination of a feedback gain that can realize a suitable feedback control characteristic quickly and reliably.

5. The invention is applied to the running control of an automatic guidance vehicle (AGV), where the optimum values of the P, I, and D gains are determined for each section of the running course. The evaluation functions used for evaluating the P, I, and D gains are suited for evaluating the stability, accuracy, and response of the running control.

6. The evaluation functions used in the invention are the ratio between the length of the voltage curve and the measurement time (LR), the product per 30 seconds of the summation of the measured voltage and a constant (Svv), and the product per 30 seconds of the summation of the absolute value of the measured voltage and a constant (Asv). These functions are suited for evaluating the P, I, and D gains, respectively.

7. The invention provides a method of determining feedback gain that is easy to use and can quickly determine the optimum values of the P, I, and D gains, and is applicable to various types of control subjects, including the running control of an AGV. The method can be used

<summary>

1. The invention relates to zoom lenses with increased relative aperture and good optical performance over the entire zooming range, while minimizing physical size and total length. The demand for such lenses comes from photographic cameras and video cameras, particularly the latter due to its relatively low image pickup element sensitivity. The 2/3 in. image pickup tube is widely used in video cameras, but the 1/2 in. image pickup tube or plate is also being used in 8 mm video cameras. The zoom lens of the invention aims to provide a small F-number, high zoom ratio, and standard image angle at the wide angle end.

2. The zoom lens of the invention comprises five lens units, including a first lens unit of positive power for focusing, a second lens unit of negative power with a magnification varying function, and a third lens unit of negative power for compensating for the shift of an image plane. The fourth lens unit has a positive lens for making the diverging light beam from the third lens unit almost parallel, and the fifth lens unit has an image forming function with six lens elements of positive, negative, positive, negative, positive, and positive powers. The lens units are designed to satisfy specific conditions to achieve good correction of aberrations and high-grade optical performance. The conditions include the range of refracting power for the rear surface of the first lens in the fourth lens unit and the range of refractive power ratio for the second lens in the fifth lens unit.

3. The inequalities of condition (1) to (4) are defined to ensure good correction of aberrations, including spherical aberration, coma, astigmatism, and chromatic aberrations. The conditions also ensure that the residual aberrations of the zoom section are corrected entirely in good balance. The fourth and fifth lens units are designed in specific forms to achieve this balance, including a bi-convex lens with a rear surface of strong curvature and a fifth lens unit with six lens elements of specific powers. The air separation between the third and fourth lenses is longest in the fifth lens unit.

4. Four examples of specific zoom lenses of the invention are provided, with numerical data for the radii of curvature, axial thicknesses or air separations, refractive indices, and Abbe numbers of the glasses of the various lenses.
